frameDefinitions: The Cognizers have a similarity (or dissimilarity) in their Opinion.
The Hearer receives a Message or communication on a particular Topic.
A person (the Cognizer) comes to believe something (the Content), sometimes after a process of reasoning.
This frame concerns people's knowledge or skill in certain domains.
The Self_mover, a living being, moves under its own direction along a Path.
A physical entity, construed as a point-Sound_source, emits a Sound.
frameExamples: Dr. Gerry and Mr. Pond <t>agree</t> in their impressions.
Teenage fans first <t>heard</t> about the tragedy on a popular radio show.
Based on the most recent census I have <t>concluded</t> that most Americans sleep too much.
FE Layer-1: He is an <t>experienced</t> programmer.
She <t>walked</t> along the road for a while.
listRoleDefinitions: This role marks constituents that express the set of <fen>Cognizers</fen> whose similarity of opinion is at issue.

When there is an asymmetry, <fen>Cognizer_1</fen> is the individual characterized by their similarity in opinion to <fen>Cognizer_2</fen>, whose opinion is assumed to be known.  <fen>Cognizer_1</fen> is often an external argument.

When the <fen>Cognizers</fen> are expressed separately, <fen>Cognizer_2</fen> is the one whose opinion is assumed to be known; it serves as a basis for establishing the opinion of <fen>Cognizer_1</fen>.

This role denotes an implicit question in response to which the <fen>Cognizers</fen> give their <fen>Opinion</fen>s, which are then assessed for their similarity.  The <fen>Question</fen> may concern the identitiy of a particular entity, as in the first example below, or it may be of the yes/no-type, as in the second example below.
A state of affairs believed by the <fen>Cognizers</fen>.
A phenomenon that the <fen>Cognizers</fen> are considering with respect to their <fen>Opinion</fen>.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the <fen>Cognizers</fen> are in agreement or disagreement.
The Place is the general area in which the Cognizers are in agreement or disagreement.
This role is the person who receives a Message. It is expressed as an Exteranal Argument in this frame:
The Message is the content that is communicated from one person to another. It is normally expressed as an NP Object or a finite clause Complement:
Topic is the subject matter about which the Message is communicated. It is normally expressed as a PP-complement headed by <ment>about</ment>, with or without a quantificational noun:
The <fen>Time</fen> the <fen>Hearer</fen> receives the <fen>Message</fen>.
Cognizer is the person who comes to believe something.
Words in this frame may occur with a PP headed by <ment>from</ment> which expresses the Evidence on which knowledge or belief is based:
With a target verb, the Content is usually expressed as a finite clausal Complement or an Object NP, and may sometimes be expressed by a PP:

Some verbs in this frame may occur with postverbal Topic expressions: They <t>found out</t> <fex name='Topic'>about us</fex>! More generally verbs in this frame may occur with quantificational nouns followed by Topic expressions:
An act performed by the <fen>Cognizer</fen> which enables them to figure something out.
<fen>Medium</fen> is the text created by the <fen>Cognizer</fen> to communicate that they came to believe a specified <fen>Content</fen>.
The time at which the <fen>Cognizer</fen> discovers the <fen>Content</fen>.
The location at which the <fen>Cognizer</fen> realizes the <fen>Content</fen>.
The person whose expertise is assessed.
<fen>Skill</fen> identifies the <fen>Protagonist</fen>'s talent or ability to do things with one's hand or body.
The area of knowledge (as opposed to a practical skill) in which the <fen>Protagonist</fen> 's experience is assessed.
A  product of behavior that shows the <fen>Protagonist</fen>'s skill or lack of skill.

This frame element can only occur in place of a skill expression. It refers to the prototypical patient in an action involving the Protagonist. For instance, in the following sentence  the children are experts at some (contextually given) action such as rolling the hoops.

<fex name='Protagonist'>Some children</fex> <m>were</m> <fex name='Degree'>quite</fex> <t>expert</t> <fex name='Focal_participant'>with wooden hoops</fex>.
This frame element denotes a role in which the protagonist has developed his expertise.
The <fen>Time</fen> when the <fen>Protagonist</fen> has the expertise.
<fen>Self_mover</fen> is the living being which moves under its own power. Normally it is expressed as an external argument.

<fen>Source</fen> is used for any expression which implies a definite starting-point of motion.
In prepositional phrases, the prepositional object expresses the starting point of motion.  With particles, the starting point of motion is understood from context.
<fen>Path</fen> is used for any description of a trajectory of motion which is neither a <fen>Source</fen> nor a <fen>Goal</fen>.  This includes 'middle of path'' expressions.
<fen>Goal</fen> is used for any expression which tells where the <fen>Self_mover</fen> ends up as a result of the motion.

<fen>Area</fen> is used for expressions which describe a general area in which motion takes place when the motion is understood to be irregular and not to consist of a single linear path.  Note that this role should not be used for cases when the same phrase could be used with the same meaning with a non-motion target, since these should be annotated with the <fen>Place</fen> FE.
The direction that the <fen>Self_mover</fen> heads in during the motion.
The time when the motion occurs.

The <fen>Place</fen> is the location within which a defined motion takes place.  Any specified or implied  <fen>Source</fen>, <fen>Path</fen> or <fen>Goal</fen> should designate a location contained with the <fen>Place</fen>.  This role can be differentiated from <fen>Area</fen> by the fact that the annotated phrase can be used in the same meaning with non-motion targets.

The frame element <fen>Sound_source</fen> is assigned to a constituent referring to a physical entity which emits a sound. Such an entity must have an appropriately complex internal structure such that it can create a sound. For example, a machine or some other thing with moving parts can create sound by itself.

The frame element <fen>Sound</fen> is incorporated in the meaning of the verbs of this frame. Otherwise, this role is assigned to NPs which actually refer to a sound in the presence of the target. This typically occurs when the target is a verb used as a modifier in its <ment>-ing</ment> form, e.g.:
An event in which one or more <fen>Sound_source</fen>s participate and which is accompanied by <fen>Sound</fen>.
The time when the <fen>Noisy_event</fen> occurs.

The location of the <fen>Sound_source</fen>. This role differs from <fen>Location_of_source</fen> only in terms of point of view; the latter role implies a point of view that is not on the <fen>Sound_source</fen>.
listRoleExamples: I think we see eye to eye <fex>in our ultimate goal</fex>, which is that we want to see a democratic Serbia.
We agree <fex>that babies should not be dropped from helicopters</fex>.
<fex>The students</fex> heard from Pat that class was canceled.
The students heard <fex>the news</fex>.
The students heard <fex>about class</fex>.
I heard <fex>in June</fex> that Pablo left, how sad!
<fex>Sue</fex> realized that Bob was lost.
I have learned <fex>from experience</fex> that poison oak can be painful.
The President learned <fex>that the reporters were hungry</fex>.
The jury learned something terrible <fex>about the suspect</fex>.
<fex>A post-mortem examination</fex> was unable to ascertain the cause of death.
<fex>Back at the tailor's shop</fex>, I deduced that our murderer was not the owner of the kerchief.
A skillful <fex>advertising campaign</fex> persuaded voters that his opponent was soft on crime.
His prowess <fex>as a surgeon</fex> is impressive.
<fex>Fred</fex> crawled the narrow passage.
The cat ran <fex>out of the house</fex>.
The scouts hiked <fex>through the desert</fex>.
The children skipped <fex>into the park</fex>.
The mouse scurried <fex>about</fex>.
You should walk <fex>south</fex> about a block .
The hitchhikers walked <fex>in the middle of the road</fex>.
<fex>The wind</fex> howled.
The branches made a rattling <fex>sound</fex>.
<fex>The conversations</fex> droned on
It's going to beep again <fex>in two minutes</fex>.
A bat squeaked <fex>over our heads</fex>.
